required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Role of the Environment and Endocrine Disruptors in Child Cryptorchidism
clinical_study.official_title: Role of the Environment and Endocrine Disruptors in Child Cryptorchidism

brief_summary.textblock: Cryptorchidism is the most frequent congenital defect of the male newborn. It requires surgery in childhood, increases the risk of fertility disorders and cancer. As a major public health objective, it's the subject of numerous recommendations. Its frequency is increasing in some countries faster than a single genetic cause could not explain it. It may occurs in a geographic cluster. The cause of cryptorchidism involves genetic, hormonal and environmental factors. Animal studies suggest that endocrine disruptors interfere with fetal testicular migration. The aim of the study is to find out if some environmental exposition may be associated with cryptorchidism.

detailed_description.textblock: Cryptorchidism is the most frequent congenital defect of the male newborn. It requires surgery in childhood, increases the risk of fertility disorders and cancer. As a major public health objective, it's the subject of numerous recommendations. Its frequency is increasing in some countries faster than a single genetic cause could not explain it. It may occurs in a geographic cluster. The cause of cryptorchidism involves genetic, hormonal and environmental factors. Animal studies suggest that endocrine disruptors interfere with fetal testicular migration. The aim of the study is to find out if some environmental exposition may be associated with cryptorchidism.

primary_outcome.measure: frequency of the job exposure of the parents of endocrine disruptors
primary_outcome.description: Measure of the frequency of endocrine disruptors assessed by european questionary QLK4-1999-01422 (simplified version )

secondary_outcome.measure: comparison of cryptorchid and non-cryptorchid children born to parents with isolated exposure vs multiple exposures
secondary_outcome.description: Assessement by the Job-exposure matrix EDC (Environment disrupting chemicals)

secondary_outcome.measure: Comparison of frequencies of exposure to endocrine disruptors (Environmental Disrupting Chemicals) in parents giving birth to a congenital cryptorchid child vs child not cryptorchid at birth but with secondary cryptorchidism.
secondary_outcome.description: presence of cryptorchidism at birth or secondarily

secondary_outcome.measure: identify food exposure criteria (phytoestrogen or EDC pesticides) associated with the presence of a cryptorchid.
secondary_outcome.description: parents will be asked about their diet

secondary_outcome.measure: Constitution of collection of biological samples from children with non-palpable bilateral cryptorchidism
secondary_outcome.description: The aim is only to make a collection of blood samples. Anonymous samples will be used later in order to improve knowledge of the cryptorchidism.

intervention.intervention_name: Measure of the exposure of parent of male with /without cryptorchidism to endocrine disruptors
intervention.description: Measure of the exposure of parent of patient with/without cryptorchidism to endocrine disruptors (job exposure, during pregnancy)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- Parents of male children from the neonatal period to 18 years of age (during surgery) with cryptorchidism
Exclusion criteria:
- Parents of children without endocrine disease. (adrenal, hypothalamic-pituitary, phosphocalcic, thyroid, diabetes, etc.)
- Parents of children without an associated genital or urinary defect (hypospadias, micropenis, renal and bladder abnormalities)
- Testicular Ectopia (testis outside of normal migration path)
- Anorchidism and evanescent testicles, united or bilateral
- Abnormalities of the abdominal wall (laparoschisis, omphalocele, Prune Belly)
- Cryptorchidism integrating in the context of a polymalformative syndrome, including neurological.
